{{infobox book | | name = Apologia Pro Vita Sua | title_orig = | translator = | image = Title page of the first edition of Apologia Pro Vita Sua.jpg | caption = Title page of the first edition. | author = [[John Henry Newman]] | cover_artist = | country = England | language = English | genre = | publisher = Longman, Green, Longman, Roberts & Green | release_date = 1864 | media_type = | pages = | isbn = }} '''''Apologia Pro Vita Sua''''' ([[Latin]]: ''A defence of one's own life'') is [[John Henry Newman]]'s defence of his religious opinions, published in 1864 in response to [[Charles Kingsley]] of the Church of England after Newman quit his position as the Anglican vicar of St. Mary's, Oxford.
==Description== John Henry Newman was regarded as a premier religious figure even before writing this definitive essay. The backdrop for the essay was a mid-century Anglican theological controversy in which Newman and other Anglicans were calling for a return to a former more disciplined and traditional authoritarian hierarchy.
Friction during the years from 1833 to 1841 led Newman and his allies in the Oxford Movement to publish a statement, the ''Tracts for the Times'', to which Newman was a contributor. The tensions culminated in Newman's 1845 resignation as Anglican vicar of St. Mary's, Oxford and his departure from the Anglican church seeking the Roman Catholics.<sup>[[Apologia Pro Vita Sua#cite note-1|[1]]]</sup>
One of Newman's rivals was Anglican [[Charles Kingsley]] of the [[broad church]] party, who responded to Newman's departure with attacks impeaching his truthfulness and honor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newmanreader.org/works/apologia65/index.html|title=Apologia pro Vita Sua|last=Newman|first=John Henry|date=|website=newmanreader.org|publisher=|access-date=23 September 2016}}</ref> The flowing, almost poetic prose of the Apologia Pro Vita Sua was a spiritual autobiographical defense to Kingsley's attacks.
Newman's book was influential with both churches and Newman was ultimately ordained by the Roman Catholics, where he soon became established as one of the foremost exponents of [[Catholicism]] in England.<sup>[[Apologia Pro Vita Sua#cite note-1|[1]]]</sup>
The book was very well received and became a bestseller, remaining in print today. A revised version of the ''Apologia Pro Vita Sua'' with many passages rewritten and some parts omitted, was published in 1865.<ref>Svaglic, Martin J. (1952). "The Revision of Newman's 'Apologia'," ''Modern Philology,'' Vol. 50, No. 1, pp. 43–49.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Colby, Robert A. (1953). "The Poetical Structure of Newman's 'Apologia Pro Vita Sua'," ''The Journal of Religion,'' Vol. 33, No. 1, pp. 47–57. * Deen, Leonard W. (1962). "The Rhetoric of Newman's ''Apologia''," ''ELH,'' Vol. 29, No. 2, pp. 224–238. * Peterson, Linda H. (1985). "Newman's Apologia Pro Vita Sua and the Traditions of the English Spiritual Autobiography," ''PMLA,'' Vol. 100, No. 3, pp. 300–314. * [[Wilfrid Philip Ward|Ward, Wilfrid]] (1913). Introduction to [https://archive.org/stream/a599543500newmuoft#page/n5/mode/2up ''Apologia Pro Vita Sua.''] London: Oxford University Press, pp. v–xxx.
==External links== * [https://archive.org/details/a676961900newmuoft ''Apologia Pro Vita Sua,''] at [[Internet Archive]]{{gutenberg|no=19690|name=Apologia Pro Vita Sua}} * [http://www.litencyc.com/php/sworks.php?rec=true&UID=6555 Literary Encyclopedia article] * [http://www.newmanreader.org/works/apologia/index.html Full text at Newman Reader site]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} [[File:Abdul-baha in Paris.jpg|thumb|`Abdu'l-Bahá, near the [[Eiffel Tower]] in Paris, 1913.]] {{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in France''' started after French citizens observed and studied the religion in its native [[Persia]] in the 19th century.[http://bahai-library.com/lambden_saiedi_gate_heart Gate of the Heart: Understanding the Writings of the Báb, by Nader Saiedi: Review by Stephen Lambden], published in The Journal of the American Oriental Society, 130:2, 2010–04 Following the introduction of followers of the religion shortly before 1900, the community grew and was assisted by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]]'s trip to France in 1911 and 1912.{{citation |last = Balyuzi |first = H. M. |author-link = Hasan M. Balyuzi |year = 2001 |title = `Abdu'l-Bahá: The Centre of the Covenant of Bahá'u'lláh |edition = Paperback|publisher = George Ronald |place = Oxford, UK |isbn = 0-85398-043-8 | ref = harv| pages=159–397, 373–379}} After growth and tribulation, the community established its National Assembly in 1958. The community has been reviewed a number of times by researchers.{{cite encyclopedia | first = Pierre | last = Larousse | author-link = Pierre Larousse| first2 = Claude | last2 = Augé | encyclopedia = Nouveau Larousse illustré: dictionnaire universel encyclopédique | title = Babisme | contribution-url =http://ia600400.us.archive.org/BookReader/BookReaderImages.php?zip=/32/items/nouveaularoussei01laro/nouveaularoussei01laro_jp2.zip&file=nouveaularoussei01laro_jp2/nouveaularoussei01laro_0677.jp2&scale=1&rotate=0 | url =https://archive.org/details/nouveaularoussei01laro | volume = |page=647 | publisher = | year = 1898 | id = | accessdate = 8 December 2012}}{{Cite encyclopedia | last = Cannuye | first = Christian | editor-last = Longton |editor-first = J. | title = Les Bahá'ís | encyclopedia = Fils d'Abraham |publisher = S. A. Brepols I. G. P. and CIB Maredsous| year=1987 |isbn= 2503823475 | accessdate= |url= http://www.cibmaredsous.be/CIBF49.HTM}}{{Cite book | last = Gouvion | first = Colette | authorlink = Colette Gouvion | last2 = Jouvion | first2 = Philippe |authorlink2 = Philippe Jouvion | title = The Gardeners of God: an encounter with five million Bahá’ís (trans. Judith Logsdon-Dubois from "''Les Jardiniers de Dieu''" published by Berg International and Tacor International, 1989) |publisher= Oneworld |year=1993 |location= Oxford, UK |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_mnYAAAAMAAJ |isbn=1-85168-052-7}} According to the 2005 [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] data there are close to some 4,400 Bahá'ís in France{{cite web| title = Most Bahá'í Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | accessdate = 3 May 2010}} and the French government is among those who have been alarmed at the treatment of Bahá'ís in modern Iran.[http://bahai-library.com/newspapers/1996/042596-1.html UN Commission expresses concern over human rights violations in Iran] == Early days == === Before 1900 === A French agent working in Persia reported briefly on the [[Bábism|Bábís]], a predecessor religion to the Bahá'í Faith, in the 1840s after it originated in 1844.[http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_western_accounts Early Western Accounts of the Babi and Bahá'í Faiths] by Moojan Momen Though in no way espousing his beliefs, [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'í]]s know [[Arthur de Gobineau]] as the person who obtained the only complete manuscript of the early history of the [[Bábism|Bábí]] religious movement of [[Persian Empire|Persia]], written by Haji Mírzá Jân of [[Kashan]],{{ref}} who was put to death by the Persian authorities about 1852. The manuscript now is in the [[Bibliothèque Nationale]] at [[Paris]]. He is also known to students of the [[Bábism|Bábí Faith]] for having written the first and most influential account of the movement, displaying a fairly accurate knowledge of its history in ''Religions et philosophies dans l'Asie centrale''. An addendum to that work is a bad translation of the Báb's Bayan al-'Arabi, the first Bábí text to be translated into a European language. [[Bahá'u'lláh]], founder of the Bahá'í Faith in the 19th century, addressed a number of items to French officials or in circumstances related to France from circa the 1870s. There were two Tablets to Emperor [[Napoleon III]] incorporated into major works of the literature of the Bahá'í Faith: the [[Súriy-i-Mulúk]] and the [[Kitáb-i-Aqdas]]. In the first it said the sincerity of the Emperor's claims on behalf of the oppressed and the helpless were tested. In the second he prophesies that, failing that sincerity, his kingdom would be "thrown into confusion", the "empire shall pass" from him and the people experience great "commotions".{{cite book| author=Bahá'u'lláh| authorlink=Bahá'u'lláh| year=1873|title=The Kitáb-i-Aqdas: The Most Holy Book| publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust| location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA| isbn=0-85398-999-0|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-6.html#pg53}}{{Cite book| last = de Vries| first = Jelle| title = The Babi Question You Mentioned--: The Origins of the Bahá'í Community of the Netherlands, 1844–1962| publisher = Peeters Publishers| year = 2002| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=n_lb9-jz6z4C&printsec=frontcover | pages = 40, 47, 52, 93, 97, 113, 133, 149, 153, 170, 175, 201, 248, 265, 290, 291, 295, 347| isbn = 978-90-429-1109-3 | ref = harv}}{{cite web | last = compiled and edited by Jonah Winters | title =Overview of the Tablets to Napoleon | work =Study Guides | publisher =Baha'i Library Online | year =2002 | url =http://bahai-library.com/resources/tablets-notes/lawh-napoleon/overview.html| accessdate = 17 August 2012}}{{cite web | last =Winters | first = Jonah | title =Second Tablet to Napoleon III (Lawh-i-Napulyún): Tablet study outline | work = Study Guides | publisher = Baha'i Library Online | date =17 October 2003 | url =http://bahai-library.com/wilmette_lawh_napulyun_outline | accessdate = 17 August 2012}} Bahá'u'lláh also criticizes the French Ambassador in Constantinople for having conspired with the Persian Ambassador saying he has neglected the exhortations of Jesus Christ as recorded in the Gospels and advises him, and those like him, to be just and not to follow the promptings of the evil within their own selves.{{Cite book|last = Taherzadeh| first = A.| author-link = Adib Taherzadeh| year = 1977| title = The Revelation of Bahá'u'lláh, Volume 2: Adrianople 1863–68|publisher = George Ronald| place = Oxford, UK| isbn = 0-85398-071-3| url =http://www.peyman.info/cl/Bahá'í/Others/ROB/V2/p301-336Ch15.html#p319}} Another tablet – the [[Summons of the Lord of Hosts#Lawh-i-Fu'ád (Tablet of Fu'ád Páshá)|Tablet of Fu'ad]] – was written soon after the death of [[Mehmed Fuad Pasha|Fu'ád Páshá]] in Nice. The Pasha was the foreign minister of the Sultan and a faithful accomplice of the Prime Minister in bringing about the exile of Bahá'ú'lláh to [[Acre, Israel|'Akka]] then in Palestine.{{cite magazine | title = Three Momentous Years of the Heroic Age −1868-70 |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1970 | number = 474 |pages=5–9 | url =}} However, Bahá'u'lláh's tablets had little attention if any in France itself. Instead the French were still occupied much more with the Báb's dramatic life and the persecution his religion and life were subject to. French writer [[Henri Antoine Jules-Bois]] says that: "among the littérateurs of my generation, in the Paris of 1890, the martyrdom of the Báb was still as fresh a topic as had been the first news of his death. We wrote poems about him. [[Sarah Bernhardt]] entreated [[Catulle Mendès]] for a play on the theme of this historic tragedy." The French writer A. de Saint-Quentin also mentioned the religion in a book published in 1891. For all the attention, little penetrated to understanding the religion itself.[http://bahai-library.com/linard_bibliographie_francais_1844-1944 Bibliographie des ouvrages de langue française mentionnant les religions babie ou baha’ie (1844–1944)] compiled by Thomas Linard, published in Occasional Papers in Shaykhi, Babi and Bahá'í Studies, 3, 1997–06 In late 1894 [[May Maxwell|May Bolles]] (later Maxwell) moved to [[Paris]] with her mother and brother, who was to attend the [[École des Beaux-Arts]],{{Cite book |author1=Van den Hoonaard |author2=Willy Carl |year=1996 |title=The Origins of the Bahá'í Community of Canada, 1898–1948 |publisher= Wilfrid Laurier University Press |isbn=0-88920-272-9| pages = 36–39}} May’s mother hoped the change from living in America would help May find a happy life, however she continued through periods of deep depression and [[insomnia]] and even considered entering a [[convent]]. In 1897 May lost both her grandmother and cousin whom she was very close to. At age 27, May became obsessed with mortality and became bedridden leading to many of her family members believing she was going to die.{{Cite book |author=Nakhjavani, Violette |year=1996 |title=Maxwells of Montreal, The |publisher= George Ronald |isbn=978-0-85398-551-8 |pages=52, 70}} In November 1898 family friend [[Phoebe Hearst]], with [[Lua Getsinger]] and others, stopped off at Paris. Hearst was shocked to see 28-year-old May bedridden with the chronic malady which had afflicted her.{{citation |last1= Hogenson |first1=Kathryn J. |year=2010 |title= Lighting the Western Sky: The Hearst Pilgrimage & Establishment of the Baha'i Faith in the West |publisher= George Ronald |isbn= 978-0-85398-543-3 |page=60}} She invited May to sojourn to the East with her, believing the change of air to be conducive to her health. Getsinger also disclosed to May the purpose of the journey: a pilgrimage to visit the then head of the Bahá’í Faith: [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]]. They arrived in early December. Transformed by the trip in just a few days, May returned to Paris about late-December where she stayed for some time, at the request of `Abdu'l-Bahá, living as a confirmed Bahá'í and began teaching her new faith. 1898 is considered as the first presence of the religion in France and the beginnings of the first Bahá'í community in Europe.{{cite book |last=Warburg |first=Margit | editor = Peter Smith |title= Bahá'ís in the West | publisher= Kalimat Press |year=2004 |pages= 5, 10, 12, 15, 22, 36, 37, 79, 187, 188, 229 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=x7wyJdyE60oC&pg=PA228&source=gbs_search_s&sig=hlmFDBtqxOwDtX3by7wn6EYCqec#PPA233,M1 | isbn = 1-890688-11-8 }} That is also the year the French [[Nouveau Larousse illustré|''Encyclopaedia of Larousse'']] contained an entry on the Bábí religion. === From 1900 to World War I === About 1900 Frenchman {{Interlanguage link multi|Hippolyte Dreyfus|fr|3=Hippolyte Dreyfus-Barney}} and American [[Laura Clifford Barney]] learned of the religion in Paris from Bolles.[http://bahai-library.com/dreyfus-barney_biography_hippolyte_dreyfus-barney Biography of Hippolyte Dreyfus-Barney] by Laura C. Dreyfus-Barney and Shoghi Effendi, edited by Thomas Linard, 1928 Dreyfus would be the first French Bahá'í and the couple would marry a decade later. Barney went to Egypt in the spring of 1901 to see [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] and returned with [[Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl]] Gulpáygání, one of the most erudite scholars of the religion, to Paris, where Anton Haddad translated for him. At the time, Paris had the most important Bahá'í community in Europe and many of those who were becoming Bahá'ís there would in later years would be famous in the religion. During Gulpaygani's time there, more than thirty became Bahá'ís. From Paris Gulpaygani went to America in the autumn of 1901.[http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_abul-fadl_gulpayganiGulpáygání, Mirza Abu'l-Fadl] by Moojan Momen At almost the same time Englishman [[Thomas Breakwell]] was also taught the religion by Bolles in the summer of 1901 in Paris.Philip Hainsworth, ‘Breakwell, Thomas (1872–1902)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/52579, accessed 21 November 2010] At the request of `Abdu'l-Bahá, Breakwell also took up permanent residence in Paris, where he worked enthusiastically to teach the religion and help develop the first Paris Bahá’í community. Breakwell regularly corresponded with `Abdu’l-Bahá‘s secretary and translator Yúnis Khán and was the first western Bahá’í to give the [[Huqúqu’lláh]], a voluntary payment based on any wealth in excess of what is necessary to live comfortably. Breakwell died of tuberculosis on 13 June 1902, barely a year after joining the religion though his father followed him into the religion. After learning of the Bahá'í Faith in Washington DC near 1898 [[Juliet Thompson]] traveled to Paris at the invitation of Barney's mother.{{cite magazine | title = Early American Bahá'ís Honor Juliet Thompson at Memorial Service in House of Worship |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1957 | number = 313 |pages=10–11 | url =}} Later in 1901 in Paris she met Breakwell who gave her Gobineau's description in French of the [[Execution of the Báb]] which confirmed her faith. Turn of the century Paris is also where [[Charles Mason Remey]] first met Thompson when she was taking classes on the religion from Gulpáygání. Bolles also introduced the religion to French-American Edith MacKaye who then moved from Paris to [[Sion, Switzerland]] in 1903 as the first Bahá'í to live in that country.{{cite journal | last = Vader | first =John-Paul | title =Selected episodes from the early history of the Bahá’í Faith in Switzerland | journal =Ezri Center for Iran and Persian Gulf Studies, University of Haifa | date =27 October 2009 | url =http://bahai-library.com/pdf/2011_09/vader_history_bahai_switzerland.pdf | accessdate = 2012-08-17}} Bolles would later leave France, being married in London and moved to Canada.{{Cite book | last = Van den Hoonaard | first = Will C. | title = The Origins of the Bahá'í Community of Canada; 1898–1948 | publisher = Wilfrid Laurier University Press | year = 1996 | location = Canada | pages = 185, 273| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=znXIbkNA1nQC&lpg=PA247&ots=9DqlD6REsD&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q=&f=false | isbn = 978-0-88920-272-6}} In 1903 Dreyfus went with [[Lua Getsinger]] and Edith Sanderson to see `Abdu'l-Bahá. Over following decades Dreyfus would translate many Bahá'í writings and serve in delegations to the Shah of Persia protesting the treatment of Bahá'ís. Modern Iranian government [[Allegations of Bahá'í involvement with other powers|allegations]] against Bahá'ís claim the early 20th century French Ambassador confessed that the Bahá'í Faith was a tool of colonial expansion. Bahá'í sources indicate that the French Ambassador in Tehran, greatly impressed by the teachings of the religion and by their effect upon the people who embraced them, suggested that Bahá'ís might go to [[Tunisia]] and teach their religion there.{{cite magazine | title = BIC rebuts Iran's anti-Baha'i document |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1983 | number = 626 |pages=1–5 | url =}} But it was Dreyfus that sought out permission from the French authorities for the religion to be promulgated in Tunisia. Indeed, the Bahá‘í Faith has never been associated with a fortification of colonial occupation or Euro-American assimilation{{Cite journal | last = Addison | first = Donald Francis | last2 = Buck | first2 = Christopher | title = Messengers of God in North America Revisited: An Exegesis of `Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablet to Amír Khán | journal = Online Journal of Bahá‘í Studies | volume = 01 | pages = 180–270 | publisher = Association for Bahá'í Studies English-Speaking Europe |location = London | year = 2007 | url =http://bahaistudies.net/onlinejournal/OJBS_1_Buck_Addison_MessengersofGod.pdf |ISSN= 1177-8547 |accessdate = 2009-12-06}} – a stance supported by anthropologist [[Alice Beck Kehoe]], a well known researcher of Native Americans, who observed that the Bahá‘í Faith is considered by its members to be a universal faith, not tied to any one particular culture, religious background, language, or even its country of origin. This has been examined in issues related to Native Americans, Latin Americans{{cite magazine |title = Historical Background of the Panama Temple|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1972 |number = 493 | page =2 | url =}} and sub-Saharan Africans{{cite magazine |title = United States Africa Teaching Committee; Goals for this year |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1954 | number = 283 |pages=10–11 | url =}} affirming this approach in Bahá'í activities. Among the translations done by Dreyfus of Bahá'u'lláh's works are the [[Kitab-i-Iqan]], [[The Hidden Words]] and [[Epistle to the Son of the Wolf]]. Over the same period [[A.L.M. Nicholas]] was inspired to study the [[Bábism|Bábí Faith]] because of Gobineau though Nicholas was critical of his work and even reached to the point of calling himself a Bábí.{{cite web| last =The Báb | authorlink =Báb |others=A. L. M. Nicolas and Peter Terry (trans.) | title =The Seven Proofs; Preface – The Work of A.L.M. Nicholas (1864–1937) | work =Provisional translations | publisher = Baha'i Library Online | date =6 April 2006 | url =http://bahai-library.com/bab_nicolas_terry_proofs | accessdate = 2012-08-18}} Nicholas translated several Bábí volumes – [[Persian Bayán]], [[Arabic Bayán]], and the [[Selections from the Writings of the Báb#Dal.C3.A1.27il-i-Sab.27ih .28The Seven Proofs.29|Dalá'il-i-Sab'ih]] and ultimately he believed [[Subh-i-Azal]] was the rightful successor of the Bábí Faith, being deeply hurt at what he felt the Bahá'ís showed towards the Báb making him but the insignificant forerunner, the [[John the Baptist]], of Bahá'u'lláh. On learning with clarity of the independent status as a greater prophet acknowledged for the Báb late in his life he wrote:
I do not know how to thank you nor how to express the joy that floods my heart. So it is necessary not only to admit but to love and admire the Báb. Poor great Prophet, born in the heart of Persia, without any means of instruction, and who, alone in the world, encircled by enemies, succeeds by the force of his genius in creating a universal and wise religion. That Bahá'u'lláh succeeded Him eventually may be, but I want people to admire the sublimity of the Báb, who has, moreover, paid with his life, with his blood, for the reforms he preached. Cite me another similar example. At last, I can die in peace. Glory be to Shoghi Effendi who has calmed my torment and my anxieties, glory be to him who recognizes the worth of Siyyid 'Alí-Muhammad, the Báb. I am so happy that I kiss your hands that have written my address on the envelope which carried Shoghi's message. Thank you, Mademoiselle; thank you from the depths of my heart.
Barney and Dreyfus worked together on the editing and translation of [[Some Answered Questions]].''al-Nūr al-abhā fīmofāważāt `Abdu'l-Bahá'', Leiden, 1908; tr. L. C. Barney and H. Dreyfus as ''Some Answered Questions'', London, 1908; {{cite news | title = Literary News of Philadelphia |newspaper = New York Times | page = 27 | date = 17 October 1908 | url = http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=61768319&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=5¤tPage=0&fpo=False | accessdate = 29 December 2011}} tr. H. Dreyfus as''Les leçons de Saint Jean d’Acre'', Paris, 1909). In 1905–06 Barney visited Persia, the Caucasus, and Russia with Dreyfus. She also wrote a play ''God's Heroes''in 1910 depicting the story of [[Tahirih]]{{cite book|last = Āfāqī |first = Ṣābir|year = 2004|title = Táhirih in history: perspectives on Qurratu'l-'Ayn from East and West|publisher = Kalimat Press|location = |isbn = 978-1-890688-35-6 |pages = 36, 68|url =https://books.google.com/books?id=u_4CBxfhsnIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=tahirih&cd=1#v=onepage&q=tahirih}} named as a [[Letters of the Living|Letter of the Living]] who has been compared with [[Joan of Arc]] in the changes which they came to release by virtue of their examples. Barney and Dreyfyus married in April 1911, when they both adopted the surname Dreyfus-Barney. Extending the previous work in the [[Nouveau Larousse illustré|Encyclopaedia of Larousse]] the Bahá'í Faith was entered into the supplement published in 1906.{{cite encyclopedia |first=Pierre| last=Larousse | author-link = Pierre Larousse |first2=Claude |last2=Augé |title=Babisme |encyclopedia= Nouveau Larousse illustré: dictionnaire universel encyclopédique |contributionurl= http://ia700401.us.archive.org/BookReader/BookReaderImages.php?zip=/21/items/nouveaularoussei00laro/nouveaularoussei00laro_jp2.zip&file=nouveaularoussei00laro_jp2/nouveaularoussei00laro_0082.jp2&scale=2&rotate=0 | url= https://archive.org/details/nouveaularoussei01laro |volume= Supplement |page=66 | = | year=1906 |accessdate= 8 December 2012}}{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1909|title = Tablets of Abdul-Baha Abbas|publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Committee |location = Chicago, USA |page=1|id = |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TAB/tab-6.html.utf8}} Circa 1900–1908 [[Marion Jack]], who would go on to be well known for her work in promulgating the religion, learned of the religion in Paris from Mason Remey when she was a student studying painting and architecture.{{cite magazine | title = Memorial at Temple to Marion Jack|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1954 |number = 282 |pages=4–5 | url =}} A decade after they met at Bolles' home, between the journeys of `Abdu'l-Bahá to France, Laura and Hippolyte married, mutually hyphenated their last names, and continued to serve the religion. The French Bahá'ís were noted as contributing to the North American [[Bahá'í House of Worship (Wilmette, Illinois)|Bahá'í House of Worship]] even after facing the January [[1910 Great Flood of Paris]].{{Cite journal | last=True | first=Corinne |title=The Mashrak-el-Azkar| journal=Star of the West |volume=01 | issue=02 |page=5 |publisher= Bahá'í News Service |location= Chicago, USA |date = 9 April 1910 |url= http://www.bahai-education.org/star/ |editor-last = Windust | editor-first = Albert R | editor2-last = Buikema |editor2-first = Gertrude | accessdate = 3 August 2012}} ==== `Abdu'l-Bahá's journeys in France ==== {{main|`Abdu'l-Bahá's journeys to the West}} Various memoirs cover the travels of `Abdu'l-Bahá including in France.Note several volumes covering the talks given on `Abdu'l-Bahá's journeys are of incomplete substantiation—"The Promulgation of Universal Peace", "Paris Talks" and "`Abdu'l-Bahá in London" contain transcripts of `Abdu'l-Bahá's talks in North America, Paris and London respectively. While there exists original Persian transcripts of some, but not all, of the talks from "The Promulgation of Universal Peace", "Paris Talks", there are no original transcripts for the talks in "`Abdu'l-Bahá in London". See{{Cite newsgroup | title = Authenticity of some Texts | authors = Correspondence Office, Document Distribution System, Research Department of the Bahá'í World Center | date = 22 October 1996 | newsgroup = Bahai-library.com| url =http://bahai-library.com/uhj_authenticity_some_texts|accessdate = 14 March 2010}}.
* {{Cite book | last = `Abdu'l-Bahá | title = Paris Talks: Addresses Given by Abdul-Baha in 1911 | publisher = UK Bahá’í Publishing Trust | year = 2006 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=u6_pbbYVjMQC&lpg=PP1&pg=PP1#v=twopage&q=&f=false | isbn = 978-1-931847-32-2}} * {{cite book |last = Blomfield |first = Lady |origyear = 1956 |year = 1975 |title = The Chosen Highway |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust|location = London, UK |ISBN = 0-87743-015-2 |url = http://bahai-library.com/blomfield_chosen_highway | pages = 147–187; Part III (`Abdu'l-Bahá), Chapters''``Abdu'l-Bahá in London'' and ''``Abdu'l-Bahá in Paris'' }} * {{Cite book | last = Thompson | first = Juliet |author2=Marzieh Gail | title = The diary of Juliet Thompson | publisher = Kalimat Press |year = 1983 | pages = 147–223; Chapter ''With `Abdu'l-Bahá in Thonon, Vevey, and Geneva'' | url =http://bahai-library.com/books/thompson/3.html |isbn = 978-0-933770-27-0}}
===== First ===== The first European trip after leaving Acre Palestine spanned from August to December 1911, at which time he returned to Egypt for the winter. The purpose of these trips was to support the Bahá'í communities in the West and to further spread his father's teachings. When `Abdu'l-Bahá arrived in Marseille, he was greeted by Dreyfus.{{Cite web | title = Hippolyte Dreyfus, apôtre d`Abdu'l-Bahá; Premier bahá'í français | work = Qui est `Abdu'l-Bahá ? |publisher = Assemblée Spirituelle Nationale des Bahá'ís de France | date = 9 July 2000 |url =http://www.bahai-biblio.org/centre-doc/ouvrage/dreyfus/dreyfus_12.htm | accessdate = 14 March 2010}} Dreyfus accompanied `Abdu'l-Bahá to [[Thonon-les-Bains]] on [[Lake Geneva]] that straddles France and Switzerland. `Abdu'l-Bahá stayed in France for a few days before going to [[Vevey]] in Switzerland. While in Thonon-les-Bains, `Abdu'l-Bahá met [[Mass'oud Mirza Zell-e Soltan]], who had asked to meet `Abdu'l-Bahá. Soltan, who had ordered the execution of [[Núrayn-i-Nayyirayn|King and Beloved of martyrs]], was the eldest grandson of [[Naser al-Din Shah Qajar]] who had ordered the [[Execution of the Báb]] himself. Juliet Thompson, an American Bahá'í who had also come to visit `Abdu'l-Bahá while still in this early phase of his journeys, recorded comments of Dreyfus who heard Soltan's stammering apology for past wrongs. `Abdu'l-Bahá embraced him and invited his sons to lunch.{{cite book | last = Thompson| first = Juliet |author2=Marzieh Gail | title = The diary of Juliet Thompson | publisher = Kalimat Press | year = 1983 | pages = 147–223; Chapter ''With `Abdu'l-Bahá in Thonon, Vevey, and Geneva'' | url = http://bahai-library.com/books/thompson/3.html | isbn = 978-0-933770-27-0}} Thus Bahram Mírzá Sardar Mass'oud and [[Akbar Mass’oud]], another grandson of Naser al-Din Shah Qajar, met with the Bahá'ís, and apparently Akbar Mass’oud was greatly affected by meeting `Abdu'l-Bahá.{{cite book | last = Honnold | first = Annamarie | title = Vignettes from the Life of `Abdu'l-Bahá | publisher = George Ronald | year = 2010 |location = UK | url =http://www.georgeronald.com/show_book.php?book_id=217 | isbn = 978-0-85398-129-9 | ref = harv |pages=51–52}} From then he went to Great Britain. On return from Great Britain `Abdu'l-Bahá stayed in Paris for nine weeks, during which time he stayed at a residence at 4 Avenue de Camoens, and during his time there he was helped by Dreyfus, Barney, and [[Lady Blomfield]] who had come from London. `Abdu'l-Bahá's first talk in Paris was on 16 October, and later that same day guests gathered in a poor quarter outside Paris at a home for orphans by Mr and Mrs. Ponsonaille which was much praised by `Abdu'l-Bahá.{{Cite journal | last = Beede | first = Alice R.|title = A Glimpse of Abdul-Baha in Paris| journal = Star of the West | volume = 02 | issue = 18 | pages = 6, 7, 12 | date = 7 February 1912 | publisher = Bahá'í News Service | location = Chicago, USA | editor-last = Windust | editor-first = Albert R | editor2-last = Buikema | editor2-first = Gertrude | url =http://bahai-library.com/beede_glimpse_abdulbaha_paris | accessdate = 15 April 2010}} From almost every day from 16 Oct to 26 Nov he gave talks.{{cite book |author=`Abdu'l-Bahá |origyear=1912 |year=1995|title=Paris Talks |edition=Hardcover |publisher=Bahá'í Distribution Service|isbn=1-870989-57-0|url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/PT/pt-1.html.utf8 | ref = harv |pages=15–17}} On a few of the days, he gave more than one talk. The book ''[[Paris Talks]]'', part I, records transcripts of `Abdu'l-Bahá's talks while he was in Paris for the first time. The substance of the volume is from notes of Lady Blomfield,{{Cite news | title = Memorial to a shining star | newspaper = Bahá'í International News Service | publisher = Bahá’í International Community | date = 10 August 2003 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/237 | accessdate = 15 April 2010}} her two daughters and a friend.{{Cite book | last = Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink= Abdu'l-Bahá |editor1=Lady Blomfield |editor2=M. E. B. |editor3=R. E. C. B. |editor4=B. M. P. |title=Talks by Abdul Baha Given in Paris |publisher= G. Bell and Sons, LTD |year=1916 |page=5 |url= https://archive.org/details/talksbyabdulbaha029093mbp }} While most of his talks were held at his residence, he also gave talks at the [[Theosophical Society]] headquarters, at [[L'Alliance Spiritaliste]], and on 26 Nov he spoke at [[Charles Wagner]]'s church ''Foyer de l-Ame''.{{cite book |author=`Abdu'l-Bahá |origyear=1912 |year=1995 |title=Paris Talks |edition=hardcover |publisher=Bahá'í Distribution Service |isbn=1-870989-57-0 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/PT/pt-1.html.utf8 |ref= harv |pages=119–123}} He also met with various people including Muhammad ibn `Abdu'l-Vahhad-i Qazvini and Seyyed [[Hasan Taqizadeh]].{{Cite web| last = Taqizadeh | first = Hasan |author2=Muhammad ibn `Abdu'l-Vahhad-i Qazvini | title = ``Abdu'l-Bahá Meeting with Two Prominent Iranians| work = Published academic articles and papers |publisher = Bahai Academic Library |origyear = 1949 | year = 1998 | url =http://bahai-library.com/qazvini_abdulbaha_prominent_iranians| accessdate = 15 April 2010}} It was during one of the meetings with Taqizadeh that `Abdu'l-Bahá personally first spoke on a [[History of the telephone|telephone]]. From France he traveled through continental Europe until he returned to France and on 2 December 1911 he left France for Egypt for the winter. He later remarked that he had visited the Senate chamber of the Parliament but "did not like their system at all, … there was a turmoil, … two of them got up and had a fight. …This is a fiasco! …Call it a play and not the Parliament."{{Cite journal |last=Fareed |first=Dr. Ameen |title= Wisdom-Talks of Abdul-Baha |journal=Star of the West | volume=03 |issue=03 |page=7 |publisher= Bahá'í News Service |location= Chicago, USA |date=9 April 1910 |url= http://www.bahai-education.org/star/ |editor-last= Windust | editor-first= Albert R |editor2-last = Buikema |editor2-first = Gertrude | accessdate=3 August 2012}} ===== Second ===== `Abdu'l-Bahá arrived in Paris as part of the second journey on 22 January 1913; the visit would last for a couple months. During his stay in the city, he continued his public talks, as well as meeting with Bahá'ís, including locals, those from Germany, and those who had come from the East specifically to meet with him. During this stay in Paris, `Abdu'l-Bahá's stayed at an apartment at 30 Rue St Didier which was rented for him by (the now married) Hippolyte Dreyfus-Barney. Some of the notables that `Abdu'l-Bahá met while in Paris include the Persian minister in Paris, several prominent Ottomans from the previous regime, professor 'Inayatu'llah Khan, and British Orientalist [[E.G. Browne]]. He also gave a talk on the evening of the 12th to the [[Esperanto|Esperantists]], and on the next evening gave a talk to the Theosophists at the Hotel Moderne. He had met with a group of professors and theological students at Pasteur Henri Monneir's Theological Seminary; Pasteur Monnier was a distinguished Protestant theologian, vice-president of the [[Protestant Federation of France]] and professor of Protestant theology in Paris.{{Cite journal| last = Fazel | first = Seena | title = 'Abdu'l-Bahá on Christ and Christianity | journal = Bahá'í Studies Review | volume = 03 | issue = 01 | publisher = |year = 1993 | url =http://bahai-library.com/fazel_abdulbaha_christ_christianity | accessdate = 3 July 2010}} ==== Tablets of the Divine Plan ==== Later `Abdu'l-Bahá wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the United States in 1916–1917 suggesting Bahá'ís take the religion to many lands, including these. These letters were compiled in the book titled "''[[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]''", but its publication was delayed owing to World War I and the Spanish flu pandemic. They were translated and published in [[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|''Star of the West'']] magazine on 12 December 1919.{{cite book |last=Abbas |first= 'Abdu'l-Bahá |translator=Mírzá Ahmad Sohrab |title= Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url= http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}} One tablet says in part:
In brief, this world-consuming war has set such a conflagration to the hearts that no word can describe it. In all the countries of the world, the longing for universal peace is taking possession of the consciousness of men. There is not a soul who does not yearn for concord and peace. A most wonderful state of receptivity is being realized.… Therefore, O ye believers of God! Show ye an effort and after this war spread ye the synopsis of the divine teachings in the British Isles, France, Germany, Austria-Hungary, Russia, Italy, Spain, Belgium, Switzerland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Holland, Portugal, Rumania, Serbia, Montenegro, Bulgaria, Greece, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Monaco, San Marino, Balearic Isles, Corsica, Sardinia, Sicily, Crete, Malta, Iceland, Faroe Islands, Shetland Islands, Hebrides and Orkney Islands.{{cite book |author= `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year=1991 |title= Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition= Paperback |publisher= Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location= Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-87743-233-3 |url= http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-6.html |page=43 |origyear= 1916–17}}
== Development and trials == === Period around the World Wars === [[Agnes Alexander]], who had been through Paris October 1900 but encountered the religion elsewhere, was back near France as World War I broke. She was in Europe seeking passage to Japan because of directions from `Abdu'l-Bahá. She found opportunity as she passed through France riding in a third class coach with two wounded soldiers and arriving safely at Marseilles substituting on a ticket of a German woman.{{cite magazine |title = Agnes Alexander: 70 years of service |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1983 | number = 631 |pages=6–11 | url = |ISSN=0195-9212}} Curtis Kelsey{{cite magazine | title = CABLEGRAM RECEIVED FROM HAIFA, ISRAEL |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1970 | number = 469 | page =12 | url =}} and [[Richard St. Barbe Baker]]{{cite magazine |title = Richard St. Barbe Baker: 1889–1982|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1982 | number = 469 | page =7 | url =}} were or would become Bahá'ís who served in France during the First World War. [[Edna M. True]], a Bahá'í since 1903 and daughter of (later named Hand of the Cause) [[Corinne True]], was a member of the [[Smith College]] Relief Unit serving in France ministering to the needs of U.S. servicemen.{{cite magazine |title = Edna M. True: 1888–1988|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1988 | number =94 |pages=2–3 | url = | ISSN=0195-9212}} In 1928 the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] of Paris was elected.''The Bahá'í World: A Biennial International Record, Volume II, 1926–1928'' (New York City: Bahá'í Publishing Trust, 1928), 182–85. That winter Hippolyte Drefus-Barney died.{{cite magazine | title = Distinguished, beloved servant passes away |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1929 | number = 29 |pages=2–3 | url =}} The funeral services included Mountfort Mills as a representative of the National Spiritual Assembly of the United States and conveyed that local assemblies in the US were holding memorial services for him. In 1929–30 the first annual conference of ''Bahá'í Students in Paris'' was held.[http://bahai-library.com/may_ellis_maxwell_bw May Ellis Maxwell], compiled by Universal House of Justice, published in A Compendium of Volumes of the Bahá'í World I-XII, 1925–1954, pp. 516–28 In 1931 a Frenchman Gaston Hesse is noted as a staff editor of volume IV of the annual [[Bahá'í literature#Periodicals|Bahá'í World]] periodical{{cite magazine | title = The Bahá'í World (Volume Four) |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1931 | number = 51 | page =13 | url =}} and a number of Persian students traveled to France in part to review the places `Abdu'l-Bahá visited during breaks in their studies{{cite magazine | title = Bahá'í activities in other countries; France |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1931 | number = 55 | page =6 | url =}} until developments in 1938–39 brought that project to an end.{{cite magazine | title = News of East and West |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1940 | number = 139 |page =11 | url =}} In 1936 May Maxwell (formerly Bolles) held meetings on the religion in [[Lyon]] along with Persian Mírzá Ezzatollah Zabih. David Hoffman, later a member of the [[Universal House of Justice]] was able to visit Bahá'ís in France in 1945. He conveyed oral reports that the [[Gestapo]] had questioned the Bahá'ís of Paris. He reported the Bahá'ís were able to retain some literature because they could report their office had been hit by a bomb destroying materials there but left unsaid that materials stored elsewhere were untouched. Some members of the community were still present, some had died, and some had disappeared: Miss Sanderson, Mrs. Scott, Madame Hess and Mr. Kennedy were among the living, Mrs. Kennedy died, Mlle. Alcan was killed in an air-raid, Mrs. Stannard died of cancer, and Mme Monteglore was known to have been taken to a concentration camp.{{cite magazine | title = News from other lands; France |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1944 | number = 176 |pages=17–18 | url =}} Some meetings were still able to be held during the occupation. French Bahá'ís also assisted in the mechanics of publishing a number of translations of Bahá'í volumes by [[Lidia Zamenhof]] in Poland, Anne Lynch in Switzerland, and others in the 1930s and 40s.{{cite magazine | title = Memorial services honor Mrs. Anne Lynch |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1967 | number = 430 | page =2 | url =}} === After World War II === The French Bahá'í community was one of the few to remain organized in Europe coming out of WWII. The European Teaching Committee did not cover France as part of its responsibilities for reestablishing the religion in the countries of Europe.{{cite magazine |title = News from other lands; France |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1947 | number = 194 | page =9 | url =}} Indeed, events noting its relative health include a new Bahá'í convert, Mme. E. Schmitt of [[Nancy, France]], in February 1946{{cite magazine |title = European survey; France |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1946 | number = 180 | page =8 | url =}} the US national assembly establishing a bureau for international news on the religion in Paris,{{cite magazine | title = Distribution of Bahá'í News|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1946 | number = 180 | page =2 | url =}} and Duncan McAlear shared news of conditions in France at the US national convention from which a decision was reached to set up a relief committee, in June.{{cite magazine | title = Highlights of the Convention |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1946 | number = 180 |pages=4–6 | url =}} In particular the Bahá'ís of the southern states of America and eastern Canada coordinated relief packages for southern France (noting Marselles, Lyon, Hyeres and Toulouse) while the eastern states and again eastern Canada extended aid to the rest of France, Germany and Great Britain.{{cite magazine |title = International Relief; What and Where to send|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1946 | number = 185| page =10 | url =}} Fifteen contacts in Paris, three in Hyeres, two in Lyon, and one each in Marseille and Toulouse, were noted for relief shipping.{{cite magazine | title = National Committees; France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1946 | number = 186|pages=3–5| url =}} Marion Little pioneered to France from the US in 1947 and aided the formation of a publishing trust.{{cite magazine | title = Passing of Pioneer Mrs. Marion Little|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1973 | number = 506|page =13| url =}} Six French Bahá'ís are noted as still being prisoners of war in Germany where the National Spiritual Assembly of Germany petitioned for their release along with other nationals of other countries.{{cite magazine | title = Excerpts from "Geneva Exchange"|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1947 | number = 186| page =4 | url =}} The French community was summarized as elderly and relatively few in number to compare with efforts of Bahá'ís in other countries then underway{{cite magazine | title = Mildred Mottahedeh visits ten European countries|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1947 | number = 200| page =9 | url =}} though it is also the oldest and continually functioning community on the continent of Europe with new converts in Lyon. Their French language materials were also being circulated around the world.{{cite magazine | title = Correction – Paris |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1948 | number = 203| page =7 | url =}} The religion was also noted as a presence in the [[French colonial empire]] from the 1950s. See for example [[Bahá'í Faith in Laos]], [[Bahá'í Faith in New Caledonia]] and [[Bahá'í Faith in Senegal]]. However the Bahá'ís in France remained relatively small and did not penetrate into French society though Bahá'ís like [[Dorothy Beecher Baker]] traveled to Paris and Lyon{{cite magazine | title = European enrollments increase |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1948 | number = 205| page =9 | url =}} and Lucienne Migette was noted in particular in Lyon as being very active in promulgating the religion.{{cite magazine | title = A view of pioneering |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1948 | number = 205|pages=9–10, 12 | url =}} Indeed, Baker's trip signalized an engagement of French Bahá'ís and others in progress of the religion following the troubled limits of war. French Bahá'ís were in attendance at the first European Teaching Conference on 22–26 May 1948 held in Geneva which including public talks in French.{{cite magazine | title = European Bahá'ís hold first Teaching Conference|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1948 | number = 209| page =1 | url =}} The second such conference, held 5–7 August 1948 in Brussels, had Migette of Lyon as one of the speakers.{{cite magazine | title = Second European Teaching Conference|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1949 | number = 209|page =7 | url =}} In 1951 the Bahá'ís of Paris opened a Bahá'í center open 3 days of week to visitors.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1951 | number = 243| page =8 | url =}} In 1952 fourteen Bahá'ís from across Europe attended the regional conference of NGOs for the Department of Public Information of the United Nations Organizations which was held in Paris – the largest group at the conference were the Bahá'ís and Bahá'í [[Ugo Giachery]] was elected chairman of one of its committees.{{cite magazine | title = U.N Regional Conference in Paris|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1952 | number = 252|pages=13–14 | url =}} In May 1953 the first French Bahá'í conference on the promulgation of the religion was held in Lyon at which Ugo Giachery attended as well as Persians and others.{{cite magazine | title = International News; France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1953 | number = 269|pages=13–14 | url =}} As part of the [[Ten Year Crusade]] Sara Kenney of France became a [[Knight of Bahá'u'lláh]] for pioneering to [[Medeira]].[http://www.bahai-library.com/writings/shoghieffendi/mbw/sec-77.html Triple Announcement on Conclusion of Holy Year] Messages to the Bahá'í World: 1950–1957, pp. 169–171{{cite magazine|title = The Passing of two Knighs of Bahá'u'lláh|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1968 | number = 452| page =3 | url =}} In a few years she would return and serve on the National Spiritual Assembly of France. In May 1955 the first known wave of coordinated [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] who moved to live in new places were noted for France – eight adults went to: Orleans, Bordeaux, and Périgueux.{{cite magazine |title = Twelfth Pioneering Report|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1955 | number = 291|pages=7–8 | url =}} That summer Lyon hosted the first all-France Bahá'í summer school 12–20 August attracting 63 Bahá'ís from 14 locations in France among others including Bahá'ís from its earliest days in France as well as the new pioneers.{{cite magazine |title = Summer Schools and Conferences of Europe 1955; All-France Conference and Summer School|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1955 | number = 296 |pages=8–10 | url =}} This was also the event at which the future election of the French national assembly was announced – to be in 1958. The first youth conference was held in Chateauroux in February 1956.{{cite magazine |title = Youth Conference held in Chateauroux…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1956 | number = 302 |page =6 | url =}} The first local assembly of Nice was elected later in 1956.{{cite magazine |title = Local Assembly of Nice… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1956 | number = 306 |page =9 | url =}} The second France Bahá'í Summer School, 24 August – 2 September, held at [[Menton]]-Garavan, opened with a one-day Teaching Conference which was attended by 63 adult believers, 5 youth and 15 children, representing 14 French localities and 7 countries.{{cite magazine |title = International News ; Many Bahá'ís attend France Summer School|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1956 | number = 306 |pages=6–7 | url =}} In the spring of 1957 the first assembly of Orleans was elected.{{cite magazine |title = Newly established Local Spiritual Assembly of Orleans…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1957 | number = 318 |page =8 | url =}} [[Sanary-sur-Mer]] was the place of the next Bahá'í summer school at which 39 adults and others from many places in France as well as Kenya, Belgian Congo and Madagascar attended.{{cite magazine |title = International Committees; Summer School prepares France for formation of National Assembly |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1957 | number = 332 |pages=6–7 | url =}} == National community == In 1957–58 the French community was part of the regional national assembly with the [[Benelux]] Bahá'í communities.[http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation National Spiritual Assemblies: Lists and years of formation] by Graham Hassall, 2000–01 At the convention to elect the national assembly of France in 1958 was [[Edna True]] representing the US national assembly.{{cite magazine |title = First Reports of the 1958 National Conventions Reveal Bahá'ís, Newly Aware of Spiritual Forces Released by Guardian's Ascension, Resolve to Meet Challenges With Maturity, Audacity, and Dedication; United States; International Goals |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1958 | number = 332 |page =12 | url =}}{{cite magazine |title = Message From the Hands of the Holy Land to the First All-France Convention|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1958 | number = 329 |pages=15–16 | url =}} Hand of the Cause [[Herman Grossmann]] oversaw the convention of the delegates coming from twenty locations in France with 77 of the then 152 Bahá'ís of France attending with [[William Sears (Bahá'í)|William Sears]] whose travel plans landed him in France at that time.{{cite magazine |title = First National Spiritual Assembly of France, Formed Ridvan 1958, Becomes Twenty-Seventh Pillar of Faith of Bahá'u'lláh|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1958 | number = 329 |pages=17–18 | url =}} The members of the first national assembly elected were: Sara Kenny, Jacques Soghomonian, Francois Petit, Joel Marangella, Chahab 'Ala'i, Sally Sanor, Lucienne Migette, Farhang Javid, and Florence Bagley. The national assembly was incorporated according to civil law in December 1958.{{cite magazine |title = First National Spiritual Assembly of France, Formed Ridvan 1958, Becomes Twenty-Seventh Pillar of Faith of Bahá'u'lláh|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1958 | number = 340|page =10 | url =}} The second national convention had 17 delegates and the annual report detailed the community as seven assemblies, ten groups, and twenty isolated believers, with a membership of seventy-six French believers, thirty-eight Persians, twenty-eight Americans and eleven of other nationalities, for a total of 153 Bahá'ís including nine who were new Bahá'ís enrolled during the year.{{cite magazine |title = Annual Conventions Review Achievements of Past Year, Marshal Forces to Attain Remaining Crusade Goal; France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1959 | number = 341|pages=16–17 | url =}} The 1959 summer school attracted 95 attendees including 16 non-Bahá'ís to [[Beaulieu-sur-Mer]] with Dr. Hermann Grossmann, as well as Jessie Revell representing the [[International Bahá'í Council]], a predecessor to the [[Universal House of Justice]].{{cite magazine |title = Ninety-Five Bahá'ís, Contacts Participate in Bahá'í Summer School of France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1960 | number = 347|page =4 | url =}} === Division === {{main|Bahá'í divisions}} In 1960, after the death of [[Shoghi Effendi]], [[Mason Remey]] instigated a dispute among Bahá'ís over administration and was declared a [[Covenant-breaker]].{{cite web | last = Momen| first = Moojan | title = The Covenant and Covenant-Breaker |publisher = bahai-library.com | year = 2003| url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant | accessdate = 1 January 2009}} Remey succeeded in gathering a few supporters including a majority of the 1960 national assembly of France elected in April timed with Remey's announcement. The assembly was dissolved through reports of [[Hand of the Cause]] [[Abu'l-Qásim Faizi]] by early May through authority of the [[Custodians]],{{cite book |editor = Rabbani, R. |editor-link = Rúhíyyih Khanum |year = 1992 |title = The Ministry of the Custodians 1957–1963 |publisher = Bahá'í World Centre | pages = 197, 202–227, 409 |url =http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians |isbn = 0-85398-350-X}}{{cite magazine |title = An Impregnable World Community|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1960 | number = 352|pages=1–2 | url =}} nine [[Hands of the Cause of God|Hands of the Cause]] assigned specifically to work at the [[Bahá'í World Centre]] elected by secret ballot, with all living Hands of the Cause voting. An election was held to elect a new national assembly at the end of May. Its members were: Lucienne Migette, Dr. Barafroukhteh, A. Tammene, H. Samimy, Lucien McComb, A. H. Nairni, Y. Yasdanian, F. Petit, and Sara Kenny.{{cite magazine |title =NSA of Frame Elected|magazine= Bahá'í News|date=October 1960 | number = 355|page =2 | url =}} The majority of Bahá'ís stood by the Hands of the Cause during this issue. Over the years following 1966 the followers of Remey were not organized; several of the individuals involved began forming their own groups based on different understandings of succession. === Continued growth === ==== Multiplying activities ==== The 1960 summer Bahá'í school was attended by Hands of the Cause Dr. [[Adelbert Mühlschlegel]] and Dr. Ugo Giachery with 83 attendees.{{cite magazine | title = Two Hands of the Cause inspire Bahá'ís at Fifth Summer School of France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1960 |number = 356|pages=5–6 | url =}} In October 1961 Bahá'í artist [[Mark Tobey]] was the first American to have a one-man show at [[the Louvre]] and the first in some years to win the [[Venice Biennale]]. Several of the news articles of Mark Tobey's achievement mentioned his faith as well as the 190-page catalogue of the Louvre presentation that had the most mention of the religion including Tobey's own words.{{cite magazine | title = Faith gains renown through Bahá'í Artist's Exhibition at Louvre|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1962 | number = 371|pages=12–13 | url =}} From Paris the show went on to London and Brussels. In December 1961 the 50th anniversary of Abdu'l-Bahá's first trip to France was commemorated at [[Hôtel Lutetia]] with an updated translation of [[Paris Talks]].{{cite magazine |title = Abdu'l-Bahá's first visit to Europe Commemorated in Paris |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1962 | number = 372| page =2| url =}} The national assembly established the French Language Publishing Trust in 1962.{{cite magazine |title = French Language Publishing Trust Has New Headquarters |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1972| number = 492| page =24 | url =}} In 1963 the members of national assemblies around the world acted as delegates to the international convention to elect the [[Universal House of Justice]] for the first time. The members of the French national assembly were: Chahab Alai, Florence Bagley, Dr. A.M. Barafroukhteh, Sara Kenny, Lucien McComb, Lucienne Migette, Yadullah Rafaat, Henriette Samimy, and Omer Charles Tamenne. Demographically the religions expanded as follows: In 1952: 3 assemblies, 3 groups, and 6 isolated Bahá'ís.{{cite magazine | title = International News; France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1952 | number = 260|pages=13–14 | url =}} In 1959: 7 assemblies, 10 groups, and 20 isolated Bahá'ís. In 1963: 7 assemblies, 10 groups, and 18 isolated Bahá'ís.[http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63 The Bahá'í Faith: 1844–1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953–1963], Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land, pp. 46, 82. In 1979: 31 assemblies, 61 groups, and 98 isolated Bahá'ís.{{cite magazine | title = Victory Messages – The Baha'I world resounds with the glorious news of Five Year Plan victories|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1979 | number = 581| page =10 | url = |ISSN= 0195-9212}} The 1964 Bahá'í summer school was held in [[Perigueux]] with Hand of the Cause [[John Ferraby]] in attendance.{{cite magazine | title = Bahá'í Summer School Held in Perigueux, France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1962 | number = 405| page =5 | url =}} In 1976 an international conference on the promulgation of the religion was held in Paris. Hand of the Cause [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]], in her first visit to France, and representing the Universal House of Justice, attended. Some 6000 Baha'is from 55 countries attended.{{cite magazine | title = Paris Conference site is selected |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=January 1976 | number =538 |page =14 | url =}} Other Hands of the Cause also attended – [[Shu'á'u'lláh `Alá'í]], [[Collis Featherstone]], [[Dhikru'llah Khadem]], [[Rahmatu'lláh Muhájir]], [[John Robarts (Bahá'í)|John Robarts]], and [[`Alí-Muhammad Varqá]].{{cite magazine | title = Preparation for the Harvest; The International Teaching Conference in Paris |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=September 1976 | number =546|pages=2–5 | url =}} Other significant attendees include Amoz Gibson, then member of the Universal House, [[Adib Taherzadeh]], then a [[Continental Counselors|Continental Counselor]] and [[Firuz Kazemzadeh]], then member of the National Assembly of the United States. Later that year French Baha'is were noted promulgating the religion in [[Republic of the Congo]].{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Baha'is teach in Kinkala |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=January 1977 | number =550|page =2 | url =}} A representative of the French national assembly attended the first election of the National Assembly of the French Antilles.{{cite magazine | title = French Antilles |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=June 1977 | number =555|page =7 | url =}} ==== Public/Media engagement ==== Since the inception of the Bahá'í Faith, its founder [[Bahá'u'lláh]] exhorted believers to be involvemed in [[socio-economic development]], leading individuals to become active in various projects.{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Bahá'í Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | accessdate = 16 October 2009}} In France this developed from just participating in social public events but it expanded into social developments and cares which returned government appreciation and support. In 1966 the Bahá'ís participated in the International Fair in Nice handing out thousands of pieces of literature.{{cite magazine | title = Bahá'í display at the International Faith in Nice…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1966 | number = 424| page =19 | url =}} A similar exhibit took place in Marseille in later 1966.{{cite magazine | title = Marseille exhibit proclaims Faith to thousands |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1966 | number = 427| page =3 | url =}} A smaller one took place in late 1966 in [[Luchon]].{{cite magazine | title = French school proclaims faith to hundreds |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1966 | number = 429| page =13 | url =}} The exhibit opportunity in Nice repeated in 1967 and was paralleled in [[Grenoble]].{{cite magazine |title = French proclamation in two major cities |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1967 | number = 436| page =18 | url =}} In 1968 the event in Nice repeated and this time an additional venue in Montpelier had a Bahá'í display present{{cite magazine | title = French exhibits in Nice, Montpelier draw crowds |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=June 1968 | number =447 | page =7 | url =}} while a smaller event took place in [[Marseille]] and [[Saint-Cloud]].{{cite magazine | title = News Briefs |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=September 1968 | number =450 | page =15 | url =}} In 1971–72 Bahá'í youth organized a proclamation comparing and the music group [[Seals and Crofts]] after their [[Bahá'í pilgrimage]] along with related publicity.{{cite magazine | title = Recent French Activities |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=March 1972 | number =492 | page =14 | url =}} The same year the national assembly formally met with the Mayor of Monaco officially.{{cite magazine | title = Mayor of Monaco Receives Baha'is |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=March 1973 | number =504 |page =24 | url =}} In 1973 local efforts to promulgate the religion in the area of [[Clermont-Ferrand]] developed into television coverage between there and Switzerland on local television and it was reported most of the new converts were youth.{{cite magazine | title = A working holiday in the villages of France |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=October 1973 | number =511 |pages=22–3 | url =}} In early 1976 the national assembly sent all local assemblies a package of information suitable for public use about [[Bahá'í Holy Days]], and Bahá'í support for observances like [[United Nations Day]] which was in turn offered to local media.{{cite magazine | title = Media campaign has good results |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=March 1976 | number =541 |page =18 | url =}} Meanwhile, an architecture student of [[I'Ecole Superieure d'Architecture de Bordeaux]] was able to formulate a study program on "The Baha'i Faith and Architecture" which was then in turn presented to students and faculty of the school.{{cite magazine | title = Architecture student talks about Faith |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=May 1976 | number =542 |pages=8–9 | url =}} Perhaps the first national television coverage of the religion took place during the 1976 international conference held in Paris. [[Kurt Waldheim]], then secretary-general of the United Nations, sent a message in recognition of the contributions of the Baha'is to United Nations initiatives to the conference. In 1980 the European Parliament passed a resolution concerning the [[Persecution of Bahá'ís]] in Iran following the [[Iranian Revolution]]{{cite magazine | title = SUPPORT-In Strasbourg, France, the European Parliament strongly condemns Iran's persecution of Baha'is |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=March 1981 |number =542 |pages=8–9 |url =}}[http://eur-law.eu/EN/RESOLUTION-PERSECUTION-MEMBERS-BAHAI-COMMUNITY-IRAN,82180,d Resolution on the solution of the Persecution of the members of the Bahai Community in Iran] Official Journal C 265, 13 October 1980 P. 0101 which was echoed by then President [[François Mitterrand]].{{cite magazine | title = Summary of the actions taken by the Baha'i International Community, National and Local Baha'i Institutions, Governments, Non-Baha'i Organizations and prominent people in connection with the persecution of the Baha'is of Iran |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=April 1982 | number =542 |pages=2–3 |url =}} The Spiritual Assembly of [[Bron]] held a successful concert fundraiser for the United Nations [[International Year of the Disabled]] in 1981.{{cite magazine |title= Around the World; France |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1981 |number=603 |page=11 |url =| ISSN=0195-9212}} In 1983 years of contact with the [[Esperantists]] by one of the members of the Baha'i community of Nantes, France, resulted in sharing with the 25-member Assembly of the Esperanto Association copies of the "white paper" on the plight of Baha'is in Iran.{{cite magazine | title = The World; France |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=November 1983 | number =630 |page =16 |url = |ISSN=0195-9212}} In later in October a French language television program featured an artist/cryptographer's calligraphy of nine letters forming the word "Behaisme". The moderator looked up the word in a dictionary and read to an audience estimated at 19 million a brief definition of the religion. The program was rebroadcast in other French-speaking countries.{{cite magazine | title = The World; France |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=March 1984 | number =636 |page =12 |url = |ISSN=0195-9212}} In 1984 Baha'is from Marseilles to Nice in southern France worked to make the first Baha'i-sponsored float on the [[Cote d'Azur]] as part of municipal parades in [[Cavalaire]] and [[Sainte-Maxime]].{{cite magazine | title = The World; France |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=October 1984 | number =643 |page =14 |url =|ISSN=0195-9212}} Also in 1984 a 15-minute segment by the Baha'is of France was televised 29 September including parts of previously produced Baha'i films from several sources as one of five segments that made up an over-all 75-minute program entitled ''Liberte 3''.{{cite magazine | title = The World; France |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=May 1985| number =650 |page =14 |url =|ISSN=0195-9212}} In April 1985 a new national center was opened at a ceremony with attendees from government and NGOs – the President of the Senate, two representatives of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and ''Citoyens du Monde'', the [[International Federation of the Rights of Man]], and [[Amnesty International]].{{cite magazine | title = The World; France |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=August 1985 | number =652 |page =14 |url =|ISSN=0195-9212}} In 1984 an Association of Baha'i Health Care Professionals was organized by a number of Baha'i doctors in France with bylaws approved by the national assembly.{{cite magazine | title = Social/economic development – Part II of our world-wide survey; Europe/France |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=April 1986 | number =661 |page =13 |url =|ISSN=0195-9212}} In 1986 [[The Promise of World Peace]] document was shared with political leaders in France including then Prime Minister [[Laurent Fabius]], the president and vice-president of France's Parliament.{{cite magazine | title = The World; France|magazine= Bahá'í News|date=July 1986 | number =664 |page =16 |url =|ISSN=0195-9212}} In spring 1986 Baha'is in Moontpelier and Marseilles held public peace events with panelists, children, performers, NGO representatives and others for the [[International Year of Peace]].{{cite magazine | title = Special Report; The International Year of Peace; France |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=September 1987|number =678 |page =5 |url =|ISSN=0195-9212}} == Modern community == In 1987 Hand of the Cause [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]] commemorated her mother's time in France with a trip visiting the Baha'is in 17 places during a 33-day stay arriving on 11 November. Events included a two-day national conference on spreading the religion was held in Paris; seven regional gatherings throughout the country in Nice, Marseille, Annecy, Bordeaux, Nantes, Rennes and Strasbourg, and a national youth conference of more than 450 youth in Lyon.{{cite magazine | title = Special report – Recounting a memorable visit to France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1988 | number = 424|pages=1–3 | url =}} During the visit she met with the director of the ''Affairs of Cultes'' and former president of the European Parliament, [[Simone Veil]], former prime minister, then Speaker of its House of Representatives, [[Jacques Chaban-Delmas]], as well as local officials. During meetings with Baha'is and visitors she often spoke of her recent trips to Africa. Extending the background of academic interest in the religion since 1900 two volumes of the French language Catholic encyclopedia ''Fils d'Abraham'' were published in 1987 mentioning the religion:  • {{Cite encyclopedia | last=Longton | first = Joseph |language=fr | editor-last = Longton |editor-first = Joseph |title= Panorama des communautés juives chrétiennes et musulmanes | encyclopedia = Fils d'Abraham |pages=11, 47–51 (mentions Bahá'ís on) |publisher= S. A. Brepols I. G. P. and CIB Maredsous |year=1987 |isbn= 2503823440 |accessdate =2016-03-22 | url=http://www.cibmaredsous.be/cibf41.htm}}  • {{Cite encyclopedia | last = Cannuye | first = Christian | editor-last = Longton |editor-first = J. | title = Les Bahá'ís |encyclopedia = Fils d'Abraham |publisher = S. A. Brepols I. G. P. and CIB Maredsous| year = 1987| id = |isbn = 2503823475 | accessdate =|url=http://www.cibmaredsous.be/CIBF49.HTM}} In 1988 Baha'is held to large informational meetings on topics of internationalism and the environment.{{cite magazine |title = Special Report; The International Year of Peace; France |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=November 1988|number =692 |page =15 |url =|ISSN=0195-9212}} [[André Brugiroux]], well known for traveling the countries of the world,[http://www.thelongestwayhome.com/resources/gmt/great-modern-travelers-andre-brugiroux.html Great Modern Travelers: André Brugiroux] encountered the religion in 1969 in Alaska and joined it. He made a documentary film about his travels and visiting Bahá'ís, versions of which have been shown since 1977{{cite magazine | title = French Baha'i visits Haiti|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1977 | number = 553| page =13 | url =| ISSN=0195-9212}}{{cite magazine | title = The World; France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1988| number = 692| page =15 | url = | ISSN=0195-9212}} and wrote a few books published including 1984{{cite book | last =Brugiroux | first = André | authorlink =André Brugiroux | title =Le prisonnier de Saint-Jean-d'Arce| publisher =Albatros| year =1984| isbn =}} and 1990{{cite book | last =Brugiroux | first = André | authorlink =André Brugiroux | title =One People, One Planet: The Adventures of a World Citizen | publisher =Oneworld | edition =illustrated | year =1990 | isbn =9781851680290}} and has given many talks about the religion and his travels in and outside France. [[The Gardeners of God]] – Two French journalists, [[Colette Gouvion]] and [[Philippe Jouvion]] attempted an objective and unbiased study of the Bahá'í Faith through a series interviews which was published in 1993 as "Les Jardiniers de Dieu" which was translated into English. The 75th anniversary of `Abdu'l-Bahá's visit to Marseilles was commemorated at the ''Palais du Faro'' in 1989.{{cite magazine | title = The World; France|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1989 | number = 697| page =14 | url = | ISSN=0195-9212 }} The centenary of the first trip in 1911 was noted at the annual Bahá'í residential school, held in Evian from 27 August to 3 September, where participants explored what it means to be "walking in the path of 'Abdu'l-Baha" as they discussed the current activities of their communities.[http://news.bahai.org/story/854 European Baha'is mark centenary of 'Abdu'l-Baha's journeys] 3 October 2011 Revised and extended work reviewing `Abdu'l-Bahá's talks and those he met, were published as well in time with this centenary: * {{cite book | last =`Abdu'l-Bahá| authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |editor=Jan T Jasion | title = The Talks of `Abdu'l-Bahá in France and Switzerland | publisher = Librairie Bahá'íe | date = August 2011 | location = Paris, FR | url =http://www.librairie-bahaie.fr/index.php?Action=pageProduitDetail&id=584 | isbn = 2-912155-25-8}} * {{cite book | last = Jasion| first = Jan T | title = On the Banks of the Seine:The History of `Abdu'l-Bahá in France and Switzerland, 1911 and 1913 |publisher = Librairie Bahá'íe | date = August 2011 | location = Paris, FR | url =http://www.librairie-bahaie.fr/index.php?Action=pageProduitDetail&id=585%20alt= | isbn =2-912155-26-6 }} * {{cite book | last = Jasion| first = Jan T | title = They all Witnessed His Triomph: A Biographical Guide to `Abdu'l-Bahá's Western Travels |publisher = Librairie Bahá'íe | date = August 2011 | location = Paris, FR | url = http://www.librairie-bahaie.fr/index.php?Action=pageProduitDetail&id=586%20alt= | isbn =2-912155-32-0 }} Continuing to voice its concern in 1993 the French government took up issues related to the treatment of Baha'is in modern Iran.[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,MARP,,IRN,,469f38a3c,0.html Chronology for Baha'is in Iran] Subsequently, it voted in favor of a UN resolution in 1996 which expressed concern over a wide range of human rights violations in Iran in a resolution adopted by roll-call vote after last-minute negotiations failed to achieve consensus. And the government took further steps a number of times.{{Cite web |url=http://www.ambafrance-ir.org/Trial-with-seven-Baha-i-leaders-in |title=Trial with seven Baha’i leaders in Iran |access-date=24 August 2012 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130224143847/http://www.ambafrance-ir.org/Trial-with-seven-Baha-i-leaders-in |archive-date=24 February 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In 2010 they supported the international community observing the treatment of arrested Baha'i leadership.[http://www.ambafrance-ir.org/Declaration-de-Mme-Ashton,989Déclaration de Mme Ashton – Dégradation de la situation des droits de l’homme] (12 juin 2010)[http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/iran-301/human-rights-and-iran/freedom-of-expression-religion-and/article/iran-sentencing-of-seven-baha-iFreedom of expression, religion and belief – Iran: Sentencing of seven Baha'i leaders to 20 years in prison] (10 August 2010) See[[Persecution of Bahá'ís]]. In 1998 French Bahá'ís attempted to address issues with [[Mohammad Khatami]].[http://bahai-library.com/newspapers/1998/111798-4.html Bahais warn of fresh persecution in Iran], CNN Cable News Network ''Frequency 19'' is a French language [[Bahá'í radio]] and video station on the internet.{{Cite web |title= FREQUENCE 19 |publisher= Licence Libre CeCILL |url= http://f19.free.fr/f19/index.php |accessdate = 27 June 2010 }} === Demographics === According to 2005 [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] data there are about 4,440. ==Further research== *{{cite AV media | people =Julio Savi | title =Dawning of the Baha'i Faith on the European Subcontinent | medium =Youtube | publisher =Wilmette Institute | location = | date =Aug 28, 2016 | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ss76oZ48ZZs }} == See also == * [[History of France]] * [[Religion in France]] == References == {{reflist|3}} == External links == * [http://www.bahai.fr/ Official Website] of the National Spiritual Assembly of France * [http://www.bahai-biblio.org/centre-doc/etude/historique-marseille/historique-marseille.htm Historique des débuts de la foi baha'ie à Marseille, 1911] * [http://www.bahai-biblio.org/centre-doc/etude/diaporama-foi-france/histoire-bahaie-france.htm Diaporama sur les débuts de la foi baha'ie en France], 1911–1913, Par lili & Bernard Lo Cascio * [http://bahaichambery.free.fr/ Les Baha'is de Chambéry] {{Europe topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith in France}} [[Category:Religion in France]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith in Europe|France]]
