revision.text:
[[File:Granit Resort NY1.jpg|thumb|The former Granit Resort/The Hudson Valley Resort & Spa in 2015]] '''Borscht Belt''', or '''Jewish Alps''', is a nickname for the (now mostly defunct) summer resorts of the [[Catskill Mountains]] in parts of [[Sullivan County, New York|Sullivan]], [[Orange County, New York|Orange]], and [[Ulster County, New York|Ulster]] counties in [[New York (state)|New York]]. [[Borscht]], a soup associated with immigrants from eastern Europe, was a colloquialism for "Jewish". These resorts were a popular vacation spot for [[New York City]] [[Jews]] between the 1920s and the 1970s.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.brown.edu/Administration/News_Bureau/1995-96/95-062i.html |title=Catskills Institute: Jewish scholars study history, cultural significance of the Borscht Belt | publisher= [[Brown University]]| location=Providence, Rhode Island| date=November 29, 1995|accessdate= August 21, 2017| archivedate= August 20, 2017| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820162242/http://www.brown.edu/Administration/News_Bureau/1995-96/95-062i.html| deadurl=no}}</ref> Most Borscht Belt resorts hosted traveling Jewish comedians and musicians, and many who later became famous began their careers there.
The tradition of Borscht Belt entertainment started in the early twentieth century with the indoor and outdoor theaters constructed on a 40-acre (16-hectare) tract in [[Hunter, New York|Hunter]], New York, by [[Yiddish theater]] star [[Boris Thomashefsky]].<ref>https://www.npr.org/2017/08/21/545027326/jerry-lewis-on-his-borscht-belt-childhood-and-the-lonely-work-of-comedy</ref>
The 1987 films ''[[Dirty Dancing]]'' and ''[[Maureen Stapleton#Filmography|Sweet Lorraine]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080518/NEWS/80518002|title=Overnight fire destroys Heiden Hotel of 'Sweet Lorraine' fame|work=[[Times Herald-Record]]|location=Middletown, New York|publisher=Dow Jones Local Media Group, Inc.|date=May 18, 2008|accessdate=June 9, 2010|archivedate=February 1, 2013|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130201165544/http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080518/NEWS/80518002|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> reflect on the bygone era.
Beginning in the 1980s, the growth of air travel made the Catskills less attractive, so many of the resorts eventually closed, although Jewish culture has remained present. A large percentage of the region comprises summer homes and bungalow colonies (including many of the historic colonies) for [[Orthodox Jewish]] families,<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Frankfurter|first=Yitzchok|title=Ruins of the Borscht Belt|url=https://issuu.com/amimagazine/docs/epub_ami136|magazine=[[Ami (magazine)|Ami]]|date=Sep 15, 2013|issue=136|page=172|access-date=Nov 2, 2016}}</ref> primarily from the [[New York metropolitan area]], as well as year-round dwellers.
Resorts still are operating in the region, including Villa Roma, an Italian American resort, [[Soyuzivka]] and Xenia, Ukrainian cultural resorts, and the Skazka and Hotel Pine, Russian cultural resorts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skazka.us|website=Skazka.us|title=Skazka Resort|date=|accessdate=2011-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://xeniaresort.net|title=Xenia Resort|website= XeniaResort.net|date=|accessdate=2011-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russianresort.net|title=Hotel Pine|website=RussianResort.net|date=|accessdate=2011-08-25}}</ref> Additionally, motorsports enthusiasts are drawn to the area visiting the [[Monticello Motor Club]].
==History== Borscht Belt hotels, bungalow colonies, [[summer camp]]s, and קאָך-אַליינס ''kokh-aleyns'' (a [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]] name for self-catered [[boarding house]]s, literally, "cook-alones") were frequented by families of middle and working class Jewish New Yorkers, mostly [[Ashkenazi]] Jewish immigrants. [[Antisemitism]], particularly in the 1940s, '50s, and '60s, meant that they were often denied accommodation elsewhere.<ref>E. Raab and G.J. Selznick: Major Social Problems. Joanna Cotler Books, 1974 (3rd edition). {{ISBN|0060452994}}.</ref>
Some of the Catskill hotels were converted from farms that immigrant Jews had started in the early 1900s. As the area grew, it began to cater specifically to Jews, providing kosher food, synagogues, and other features of Jewish communities, including entertainment. The area became known as "The Jewish Alps", and the [[Sullivan County, New York|Sullivan County]] portion as "Solomon County".<ref name="hvmag">{{cite web | last=Levine | first=David | date=August 8, 2014 | title=History of Borscht Belt Hotels and Bungalow Colonies in the Catskills | url=http://www.hvmag.com/Hudson-Valley-Magazine/August-2014/History-of-Borscht-Belt-Hotels-and-Bungalow-Colonies-in-the-Catskills/ | work=[[Hudson Valley (magazine)|Hudson Valley]] | publisher=Today Media | accessdate=May 26, 2017 | archivedate=2016-09-18 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918130642/http://www.hvmag.com/Hudson-Valley-Magazine/August-2014/History-of-Borscht-Belt-Hotels-and-Bungalow-Colonies-in-the-Catskills/# | deadurl=no | df= }}</ref>
From the 1920s through the 1970s,<ref name="Tablet Mag">{{cite web | author=[[Marisa Scheinfeld]]| url= http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-arts-and-culture/102787/the-ruins-of-the-borscht-belt |title=The Ruins of the Borscht Belt|work = [[Tablet Magazine]]|date=June 15, 2012 |accessdate=March 2, 2013|archivedate= June 12, 2017| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170612092904/http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-arts-and-culture/102787/the-ruins-of-the-borscht-belt|deadurl=no}}</ref> nearly all notable Jewish entertainers would hone their skills at resorts in the Sullivan County area. [[Fallsburg, New York|Fallsburg]] became the catalyst for American [[stand-up comedy]].<ref name="The Last Catskills Resort">{{cite web | last=Laskow |first=Caroline| last2=Rosenberg| first2=Ian | url= http://www.thirteen.org/metrofocus/2012/01/last-resort-dirty-dancing-and-the-legacy-of-the-jewish-catskills/ |title=Last Resort: ‘Dirty Dancing’ and the Catskills Legacy | publisher=MetroFocus ([[WNET]]) |location=New York City| date=January 6, 2012|accessdate=March 2, 2013|archivedate=July 6, 2017|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170706113251/http://www.thirteen.org/metrofocus/2012/01/last-resort-dirty-dancing-and-the-legacy-of-the-jewish-catskills/| deadurl=no}}</ref> Comedy legends, including [[Woody Allen]], [[Rodney Dangerfield]], [[Jerry Seinfeld]], and [[Henny Youngman]], performed there,<ref name = "hvmag" /> as did [[Sid Caesar]], [[Billy Crystal]], [[Buddy Hackett]], [[Gabe Kaplan]], [[Andy Kaufman]], and [[Joan Rivers]].<ref name="The Last Catskills Resort" /> [[Jerry Lewis]] worked as a busboy while his parents did a vaudeville act. He would entertain customers while cleaning tables, giving him a chance to hone his skills while upping his tips.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/08/21/545027326/jerry-lewis-on-his-borscht-belt-childhood-and-the-lonely-work-of-comedy|title=Jerry Lewis On His Borscht Belt Childhood And The Lonely Work Of Comedy}}</ref><!--[[Mel Blanc]], [[Milton Berle]], [[Jack Benny]], [[Danny Kaye]] and [[Red Buttons]] made an early living at the night clubs here, as would Hollywood stars [[Mel Brooks]], [[Don Rickles]]--> Famed [[boxing|prize fighters]] like [[Rocky Marciano]] and [[Sonny Liston]],<ref name="Baltimore Sun mistake">{{cite web| url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-07-23/news/1997204072_1_concord-catskills-fallsburg| title=Unbuckling of the Borscht Belt| last=Matthews| first=Joe| date=July 23, 1997| work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]| location=Maryland| accessdate=March 2, 2013| archivedate=January 17, 2017| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170117230942/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-07-23/news/1997204072_1_concord-catskills-fallsburg| deadurl=no| df=}}</ref> and [[Muhammad Ali]], [[Leon Spinks]] and [[Floyd Patterson]]<ref name="Fighting for the Borscht Belt">{{cite web | last =Klein| first=Binnie |url=http://forward.com/articles/131273/fighting-for-the-borscht-belt/ |title=Fighting for the Borscht Belt|work = [[The Forward]] |publisher=The Forward Association| date=September 15, 2010 | accessdate=March 2, 2013| archivedate= December 21, 2016|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161221195337/http://forward.com/articles/131273/fighting-for-the-borscht-belt/|deadurl=no}}</ref> trained there. Millions of tourists, especially New Yorkers, came to swim in the lakes and oversized hotel pools, to ski or ice-skate<ref name="Tablet Mag" /> or take lessons in golf, tennis, and dancing. No fewer than 538 hotels sprang up in this area of Eastern New York.<ref name="Tablet Mag"/>
Well known resorts in the area included [[Concord Resort Hotel|The Concord]], [[Grossinger's]], [[Brickman's]], [[Brown's Hotel (Catskills)|Brown's Hotel]], [[Kutsher's Hotel|Kutsher's Hotel and Country Club]], the [[Nevele Grand Hotel|Nevele]], Friar Tuck Inn, Gibber's, Gilbert's, Granit, the Woodbine Hotel, the Heiden Hotel, Irvington, Lansman's, The Laurels Hotel and Country Club, The Pines Resort, [[Raleigh Hotel (South Fallsburg, New York)|Raleigh]], Silverman's River View Hotel, Stevensville, Stiers, the Tamarack Lodge, the Olympic, and the Windsor Regency.
Two of the larger hotels in High View (north of [[Bloomingburg, New York|Bloomingburg]]) were Shawanga Lodge<ref>{{cite web | last=Dan | first = Abby |date=n.d. | title= History | url=http://shawanga.com | publisher=Shawanga.com (fan site) |accessdate= November 11, 2016| archivedate=May 21, 2017| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170521222001/http://shawanga.com/| deadurl=no}} Collection of photographs and memorabilia.</ref> and the Overlook. In 1959, the Shawanga hosted a conference that marked the beginning of serious research into lasers.<ref name='Beam'>{{cite book | last = Hecht | first = Jeff | title = Beam: the race to make the laser | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2005 | location = Oxford, UK | page = 101 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6jOnlRViWPoC | isbn = 978-0-19-514210-5 }}</ref> The hotel burned to the ground in 1973.<ref>{{cite book | last=Roosa | first=Monoka A. | date= 2007 | title= Mamakating | publisher = Arcadia Publishing| location= publocation | page=29}}</ref> The Overlook had entertainment and summer lodging through the late 1960s and was operated by the Schrier family. It included a main building and about 50 other bungalows, plus a five-unit cottage just across the street. It remains in a different form, no longer functioning as it was in its heyday.
The [[New York, Ontario and Western Railway|New York, Ontario & Western Railway]] carried passengers to the resorts from [[Weehawken, New Jersey]], until 1948. The railroad was abandoned in 1957. Despite the improvement of roads such as the original [[New York State Route 17]], the area is no longer a major travel destination.
The decline of the Catskills resorts was apparent as early as 1965. Entertainment in America was changing as the country ushered in the [[jet age]].<ref name="Tablet Mag" /> As ethnic barriers in the U.S. began to fall and travel to distant resorts became easier and cheaper, fewer Jewish American families in New York City went to the Catskills. By the early 1960s, between a quarter and a third of Grossinger's annual visitors were non-Jewish.<ref name=AJones>{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Abigail|title=Beautiful ruins: The Catskills may be dying, but the memories live on|url=http://forward.com/articles/183901/rediscovering-beauty-amid-ruins-of-once-glorious-c/?p=all|accessdate=October 27, 2013|work=The Forward|publisher=The Forward Association| date=September 27, 2013|archivedate= March 6, 2016|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160306111031/http://forward.com/culture/183901/rediscovering-beauty-amid-ruins-of-once-glorious-c/?p=all|deadurl=no}}</ref> Even the universalization of [[air conditioning|air-conditioned]] hotels across America drew customers away from the aging resorts primarily built before this innovation became popular.<ref name="Baltimore Sun mistake" /> In the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|social and cultural upheavals of the 1960s]], traditional resort vacations lost their appeal for many younger adults.<ref name=AJones />
Smaller, more modest hotels such as Youngs Gap and the Ambassador found themselves in a niche with a vanishing clientele and closed by the end of the 1960s.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} By the mid-1990s, nearly 300 hotels and motels had gone out of business in Sullivan County.<ref name="Baltimore Sun mistake" />
The 1970s took a toll on more lavish establishments such as the Flagler and The Laurels.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5it7KmNphMo</ref> In 1986 Grossinger's closed for renovations, and the property was abandoned by new owners midway through work. Grossinger's largest historic rival (and the largest of all the Borscht Belt resorts), the Concord, benefitted only temporarily, filing for bankruptcy in 1997 and closing a year later.
In 1987, New York's mayor [[Ed Koch]] proposed buying the Gibber Hotel in Kiamesha Lake to house the homeless. The idea was opposed by local officials.<ref>{{cite news |authorlink=Joyce Purnick | first=Joyce | last=Purnick | date=April 4, 1987 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/nyregion/catskills-hotel-suggested-for-homeless.html | work=The New York Times | title=Catskills Hotel Suggested For Homeless | accessdate=April 26, 2010}}</ref> The hotel instead became a religious school, like many old hotels in the Catskills.<ref>[http://catskills.brown.edu/hotelframes.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228045158/http://catskills.brown.edu/hotelframes.html |date=February 28, 2009 }}</ref>
== Legacy == {{update|date=September 2017}}
Plans are now in place by those who purchased the former Borscht Belt resorts [[Concord Resort Hotel]] and [[Grossinger's]] to work with [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] in an attempt to bring gambling to the region. Because the Borscht Belt's prime has long passed and many of the resorts are abandoned, developers believe this is the only way to revitalize the region to the popularity it once had by attracting guests to world-class casinos and resorts such as the ones in [[New Jersey]] and [[Connecticut]].{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} However, large-scale casino plans have not come to fruition, mainly because there are no [[Indian reservation]]s anywhere near the area (the [[Mohawk tribe]]'s effort to build a Catskills casino was rejected for this very reason). Instead, the state government proposed legalizing off-reservation gambling, which required a positive referendum, passed in November 2013.
The Heiden Hotel in [[South Fallsburg, New York|South Fallsburg]], which was the location of the movie ''[[Maureen Stapleton#Filmography|Sweet Lorraine]]'' starring [[Maureen Stapleton]], was destroyed by fire in May 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080518/NEWS/80518002|title=Overnight fire destroys Heiden Hotel of 'Sweet Lorraine' fame|work=[[Times Herald-Record]]|location=Middletown, New York|publisher=Dow Jones Local Media Group, Inc.|date=May 18, 2008|accessdate=June 9, 2010|archivedate=February 1, 2013|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130201165544/http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080518/NEWS/80518002|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
The Stevensville Hotel in [[Liberty (town), New York|Swan Lake]], which was owned by the family of [[David G. Friehling]], who pleaded guilty as an accomplice of [[Bernard Madoff]]'s, has reopened as the Swan Lake Resort Hotel.<ref>{{cite news|author=Steve Israel|url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20090322%2FNEWS%2F903220321|title=Madoff mess has local link|work=Times Herald-Record|location=Middletown, New York|publisher=GateHouse Media|date=|accessdate=June 9, 2010|archivedate=2017-08-21|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6stPIKkjU?url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20090322%2FNEWS%2F903220321#|deadurl=yes|df=}} Additional [[ WebCitation archive]] August 21, 2017.</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://catskills.brown.edu/hotelnews/rebuild.html |title=Reinventing the Catskills|first=Rich|last=Newman|date=n.d.| publisher= The Catskills Institute (Brown University) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227094255/http://catskills.brown.edu/hotelnews/rebuild.html |archivedate=February 27, 2009 }}</ref>
The former Homowack Lodge in [[Spring Glen, New York]], was converted into a summer camp for [[Hassidic]] girls. Officials of the state Department of Health ordered the property evacuated in July 2009, citing health and safety violations.<ref>{{cite news |first=Victor |last=Whitman |title=New York wants sect to leave old resort |date=July 16, 2009 |work=Times Herald-Record|location=Middletown, New York}}</ref><!--dead, non-archived; presumably still available in hard copy print newspaper-->
The Granit later began operating as the [[Hudson Valley Resort]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Hudson Valley Resort|website=HudsonValleyResort.com|url=http://www.hudsonvalleyresort.com/}}</ref>
The Tamarack Lodge caught fire in 2012, and 30 buildings were partially or completely destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hudsonvalley.ynn.com/content/top_stories/579812/massive-fire-at-tamarack-lodge-visible-for-miles |title=Massive fire at Tamarack Lodge visible for miles |website=hudsonvalley.ynn.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-08}}</ref>

{{Infobox Organization |name = Broadcast ministry of the Members Church of God International |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = |extinction = |type = Religious |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Philippines]], [[Brazil]] |location = |coords = |region_served = International |membership = |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.mcgi.org www.mcgi.org] |remarks = }} Broadcast media is being utilized by the '''[[Members Church of God International|Members Church of God International (MCGI)]]''', an international Christian religious organization with headquarters in the [[Philippines]], to preach the gospel and expand internationally. The church is producing religious programs in different languages, aired in various countries, by acquiring [[brokered programming|time slots]] in several television stations. The church also maintains its own radio and television network for its 24/7 terrestrial, satellite and internet broadcasts. The MCGI started as a small group with less than a hundred believers in 1977. It is popularly known in the Philippines as '''''Ang Dating Daan (ADD)''''' (English: The Old Path), the title of its flagship radio and television program and currently the longest-running religious program in the Philippines with [[Eliseo Soriano]] (also known as "Bro. Eli") as the program's main host and the "Overall Servant" (Former title: "Presiding Minister") to MCGI. Most of its broadcast ministries are directly funded by the church, through voluntary contributions from its members, as the church do not accept monetary donations from non-members. Meanwhile, a few of its news and public affairs programs in the Philippines are supported by commercial advertisements. Its global evangelism is conducted mostly via [[AM broadcasting|AM]] radio, [[FM broadcasting|FM]] radio, terrestrial television, [[cable television]] and direct-to-home satellite transmissions. Other platforms include [[internet streaming]], [[mobile app]]lications and various forms of social media. The group also conducts regular Bible Expositions aired live via satellite in all MCGI local congregations and through the "MCGI Broadcast" mobile app. ==History== Soriano started his nightly town-to-town preaching in the 1970s but eventually realized that his lifetime is not enough to reach the entire Philippines. In 1980, he decided to go on radio and after a few years on television to preach the gospel. In 1999, the church took advantage of the advancement in internet technology. Its foray into satellite broadcasting happened in 2004, to reach more souls in different countries around the globe. In October 1980, the 30-minute radio program ''Ang Dating Daan'' was aired in [[DWAN|DWWA 1206 kHz]] with a shoe-string budget. In February 1983, the program was aired for the first time in television through [[Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation|IBC Channel 13]]. In 1997, the program moved to [[DZRJ-TV|RJTV Channel 29]], government-owned [[People's Television Network|PTV-4]] and later in [[Southern Broadcasting Network|SBN 21]]. In 1999, the church launched a nationwide radio broadcast through [[DZRH]], [[Radio Mindanao Network|RMN]] and [[Radyo Natin Network|100 Radyo Natin]] stations. ==Radio and television== The [[UNTV (Philippines)|UNTV Public Service]] channel, [[DWUN|Radyo La Verdad 1350 kHz]], [[The Old Path (TOP) Channel|TOP Channel]], [[The Truth Channel]], [[TV Verdade]] and [[TV La Verdad]] are the official religious media services of the Members Church of God International. Between 2010 and 2011, the MCGI programs reached the airwaves of [[India]], [[Uruguay]], [[Argentina]], [[Bolivia]] and [[Portugal]]. To further boost viewership, the church acquired a 30-minute slot in [[Fox Channel]] which can be seen in over 50 cable networks in [[Central America|Central]] and [[South America]]. In 2012, MCGI launched its own channel [[TV La Verdad]] (English: Truth TV) for [[Spanish language|Spanish]]-speaking countries. In 2012, through a blocktime agreement with PBC, MCGI's own radio station in [[Mega Manila]], UNTV Radio La Verdad 1350 kHz was launched. ===International broadcasts=== ''Ang Dating Daan'' is being aired internationally, with programs usually lasting for an hour or two, through [[blocktime]] agreements with local television networks. {| class="toccolours" style="margin-center:1em; font-size:100%; line-height:1.4em; width:620px;" ! colspan="1" style="text-align:center; background:#7B68EE;"| '''MCGI Local Free TV Broadcast (International)''' |- |

|} ===UNTV Public Service channel (Philippines)=== In 2004, [[DWAO-TV|UNTV-37]] became the permanent home of MCGI when it acquired an exclusive [[blocktime]] agreement with UNTV's parent, the [[Progressive Broadcasting Corporation]]. In 2007, the station became a "Public Service Channel" when MCGI affiliate Breakthrough and Milestones Productions International, Inc. (BMPI), acquired the entire production and management operations of UNTV. The station operates 24/7 in [[Metro Manila]] and surrounding provinces with a power of 60 kilowatts, with several low-powered relay stations in the provinces. UNTV was aired nationwide via [[Mabuhay Satellite Corporation|Mabuhay]] [[ABS-3|Agila 2]]. In 2011, UNTV left Agila 2 and transferred its [[free-to-air]] broadcast feed to [[MEASAT-3a]] satellite which covers [[Asia]] and selected parts of [[Australia]], [[Middle East]], [[Europe]] and [[Africa]]. UNTV is also being carried by [[Sky (cable company)|Sky Cable]] and more than 200 local [[cable television|cable operators]] and [[Cignal]], the largest direct-to-home satellite provider in the Philippines. On January 16, 2012, it was formally launched as UNTV Radio La Verdad 1350 kHz along with the UNTV Mobile Radio booth, a first in Philippine radio history.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/772205/untv-radio-launches-mobile-booth|title=UNTV-Radio launches Mobile Booth|publisher=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=January 30, 2012|accessdate=3 June 2013}} It operates in [[Mega Manila]] with a 10,000 watts output. On February 13, 2017, the station changed its branding to simply '''Radyo La Verdad 1350 kHz'''. ===TV Verdade (Brazil)=== In December 2009, the church's own religious channel [[TV Verdade]] (English: Truth TV) was launched in [[Brazil]], airing ''O Caminho Antiguo'' in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] via satellite. Its broadcast feed originates from a small garage, around 48 square meters, transformed into a makeshift broadcasting studio located in [[Florianópolis]], the capital city of the state of [[Santa Catarina (state)|Santa Catarina]]. '''Buddha's Dispensation''' (Buddha-sasana) is the time period which [[Dharma]] ([[Pali Canon]]) exist and follow. It is totally 5000 years after the Buddha's [[Parinirvana]] (pass away or "Skandha Parinirvana"). There are three types of Parinirvana. These are "Klesha Parinirwana", "Skandha Parinirvana" and "Dhatu Parinirvana".
Dhatu Parinirvana will occur the end of the Buddha's Dispensation (totally 5000 years after the Buddha's Skandha Parinirvana). It happens according to the Buddha's wish even though he doesn't exist. All Buddha's Relics in the [[Ruwanwelisaya]] (the place where a large amount of Buddha's Relics exist) in [[Sri Lanka]] will join together and make a picture of a Buddha in the sky above Ruwanwelisaya. Then those relics and all [[Relics associated with Buddha]] in the human, Naga, heaven and Brahma worlds will came to the sky above the [[Vajrasana, Bodh Gaya|Vajrasana]] (diamond throne) in '[[Bodh Gaya]]' of India and will make a complete picture of Buddha which will preach [[Dharma]] for the last time. This will not be a normal preaching like in the '[[Sutta Pitaka]]' in [[Pali Canon]]. It will be a '[[Samukkansika mode of preaching]]' extensively on 'Four Noble Truths' which preach with Buddha's super-normal abilities. This is a very long (containing many hundred thousand words) preaching, done in high speed but every one can understand each word clearly. With this preaching, many beings realize Nirvana. Then Vajrasana will come to the sky from the earth and all Buddha's Relics and Vajrasana will be completely burned out but without any ash.
After this 'Dhatu Parinirvana' and when the last [[Sotāpanna]] human passed away from the earth it is said to be the end of Buddha's Dispensation. Before the end of Buddha's dispensation any one who correctly follows Buddha's words is said to be able realize the Nirvana. But after the Buddha's Dispensation it seems it is impossible since no one has the energy to correctly follow Buddha's words. But if any great being correctly follows Buddha's words even after the Buddha's Dispensation it is said to be able to realize the reality (Nirvana).
